sen.j: 久米寺（くめでら）は、奈良県橿原市久米町にある真言宗御室派の寺院。
sen.e: Kume-dera Temple, located in Kume Town, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture is a temple that belongs to the Omuro school of the Shingon sect.
Kume-dera Temple, located in Kume Town, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture, is a temple that belongs to the Omuro school of the Shingon sect of Buddhism.
sen.cmt: ・isの前に挿入句を閉じるコンマを追加しました。・何のsectか分かるように「of Buddhism」を追加しました。
sen.e: Kume-dera Temple, located in Kume Town, Kashihara City, Nara Prefecture, is a temple that belongs to the Omuro school of the Shingon sect of Buddhism.

sen.j: 山号は霊禅山。
sen.e: Its sango (literally "mountain name," a title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple) is Mt. Reizen-zan.
Its sango (literally "mountain name," a title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple) is Reizen-zan.
sen.cmt: ・引用符の後のコンマの位置を修正しました。・山号のため、「Mt.」は削除しました。
sen.e: Its sango (literally "mountain name," a title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple) is Reizen-zan.

sen.j: 詳しくは霊禅山東塔院久米寺と称する。
sen.e: Its full name is Mt. Reizen-zan Toto-in Kume-dera Temple.
Its full name is Reizen-zan Toto-in Kume-dera Temple.
sen.cmt: ・山号のため、「Mt.」は削除しました。
sen.e: Its full name is Reizen-zan Toto-in Kume-dera Temple.

sen.j: 本尊は薬師如来。
sen.e: Its principle image is Yakushi-nyorai.
Its principal image is Yakushi-nyorai.
Its principal image is Yakushi-nyorai.

sen.j: 開基（創立者）は聖徳太子の弟の来目皇子（くめのおうじ）とも言うが未詳。
sen.e: The founder is unknown, although there is a theory that it was Prince Kume, Prince Shotoku's younger brother.
The founder is unknown, although there is a theory that it was Prince Kume, Prince Shotoku's younger brother.
The founder is unknown, although there is a theory that it was Prince Kume, Prince Shotoku's younger brother.

sen.j: 大和七福八宝めぐり（信貴山朝護孫子寺、久米寺、子嶋寺、おふさ観音、談山神社、當麻寺中之坊、安倍文殊院、大神神社）のひとつ。
sen.e: One of the Yamato Shichifuku Happo pilgrimage (Shigisan Chogosonshi-ji Temple, Kume-dera Temple, Kojima-dera Temple, Ofusa Kannon Tanzan-jinja Shrine, Taima-dera Temple Nakano-do Hall, Abe Monju-in Temple, Omiwa-jinja Shrine).

One of the Yamato Shichifuku Happo pilgrimage (Shigisan Chogosonshi-ji Temple, Kume-dera Temple, Kojima-dera Temple, Ofusa Kannon Tanzan-jinja Shrine, Taima-dera Temple Nakano-do Hall, Abe Monju-in Temple, Omiwa-jinja Shrine).

One of the Yamato Shichifuku Happo pilgrimage (Shigisan Chogosonshi-ji Temple, Kume-dera Temple, Kojima-dera Temple, Ofusa Kannon Tanzan-jinja Shrine, Taima-dera Temple Nakano-do Hall, Abe Monju-in Temple, Omiwa-jinja Shrine).

sen.j: 仏塔古寺十八尊第9番。
sen.e: The ninth temple of the 18 Historical Temples with Pagodas.
The ninth temple of the 18 Historical Temples with Pagodas.
The ninth temple of the 18 Historical Temples with Pagodas.

sen.j: 大和三山の1つ、畝傍山の南方に位置し、橿原神宮からも近い。
sen.e: One of the three Yamato mountains, located to the south of Mt. Unebi-yama and close to Kashihara-jingu Shrine.
One of the three Yamato mountains, located to the south of Mt. Unebi-yama and close to Kashihara-jingu Shrine.
One of the three Yamato mountains, located to the south of Mt. Unebi-yama and close to Kashihara-jingu Shrine.

sen.j: 開基は聖徳太子の弟・来目皇子（くめのおうじ）とも久米仙人とも伝わるが、詳細は不明である。
sen.e: The founder is unknown, although it is said that it was either Prince Kume, Prince Shotoku's younger brother, or the Kume-no-sennin (mountain wizard).
The founder is unknown, although it is said that it was either Prince Kume, Prince Shotoku's younger brother, or the Kume-no-sennin (mountain wizard).
The founder is unknown, although it is said that it was either Prince Kume, Prince Shotoku's younger brother, or the Kume-no-sennin (mountain wizard).

sen.j: 空海（弘法大師）が真言宗を開く端緒を得た寺として知られる。
sen.e: It is known as the temple where Kukai (Kobo Daishi) started the Shingon sect.
It is known as the temple where Kukai (Kobo Daishi) started the Shingon sect.
It is known as the temple where Kukai (Kobo Daishi) started the Shingon sect.

sen.j: 娘のふくらはぎに見とれて空から落ちたという久米仙人の伝説が残る。
sen.e: Legend has it that Kume-no-sennin fell out of the sky while gaping at the sight of a young woman's thigh.
Legend has it that Kume-no-sennin fell out of the sky while gaping at the sight of a young woman's calf.
sen.cmt: 「ふくらはぎ」の訳語を修正しました。
sen.e: Legend has it that Kume-no-sennin fell out of the sky while gaping at the sight of a young woman's calf.

sen.j: 『和州久米寺流記』には来目皇子の開基を伝える。
sen.e: "Washu Kume-dera Ryuki" (the record of the estate of Kume-dera Temple) tells about the founding by Prince Kume.
"Washu Kume-dera Ryuki" (the record of the estate of Kume-dera Temple) tells about the founding by Prince Kume.
"Washu Kume-dera Ryuki" (the record of the estate of Kume-dera Temple) tells about the founding by Prince Kume.

sen.j: 一方、『扶桑略記』『七大寺巡礼私記』などは当寺を久米仙人と結び付けている。
sen.e: "Fuso Ryakki" (A Brief History of Japan) and "Shichidaiji Junrei Shiki (Private Journal of a Prilgrimage to the Seven Great Temples) tie the temple to Kume-no-sennin.
"Fuso Ryakki" (A Brief History of Japan) and "Shichidaiji Junrei Shiki (Private Journal of a Pilgrimage to the Seven Great Temples) tie the temple to Kume-no-sennin.
sen.cmt: 「Pilgrimage」のスペリングを修正しました。
sen.e: "Fuso Ryakki" (A Brief History of Japan) and "Shichidaiji Junrei Shiki (Private Journal of a Pilgrimage to the Seven Great Temples) tie the temple to Kume-no-sennin.

sen.j: 久米仙人の伝説（後述）がフィクションであることは言うまでもなく、創建の正確な事情は不明だが、ヤマト政権で軍事部門を担当していた部民制の久米部の氏寺として創建されたとする説が有力である。
sen.e: Needless to say, the legend of Kume-no-sennin (later mentioned) is fiction; although accurate details of the founding are uncertain, the theory that it was built as the uji-dera temple (temple built for praying for one clan's prosperity) for Kumebe, responsible for the military division under the system of the Yamato administration, is most credible.

Needless to say, the legend of Kume-no-sennin (later mentioned) is fiction; although accurate details of the founding are uncertain, the theory that it was built as the uji-dera temple (temple built for praying for one clan's prosperity) for Kumebe, responsible for the military division under the system of the Yamato administration, is most credible.

Needless to say, the legend of Kume-no-sennin (later mentioned) is fiction; although accurate details of the founding are uncertain, the theory that it was built as the uji-dera temple (temple built for praying for one clan's prosperity) for Kumebe, responsible for the military division under the system of the Yamato administration, is most credible.

sen.j: 境内には古い塔の礎石があり、境内から出土する瓦の様式から見ても、創建は奈良時代前期にさかのぼると思われる。
sen.e: Because of the cornerstones for an old tower within the property and the style of roof tiles that have been unearthed, it is thought that construction dates back to the early Nara period.
Because of the cornerstones for an old tower within the property and the style of roof tiles that have been unearthed, it is thought that construction dates back to the early Nara period.
Because of the cornerstones for an old tower within the property and the style of roof tiles that have been unearthed, it is thought that construction dates back to the early Nara period.

sen.j: 空海はこの寺の塔において真言宗の根本経典の1つである『大日経』を感得（発見）したとされている。
sen.e: It is said that it was at the tower in this temple that Kukai discovered "Dainichi-kyo" (Mahavairocana Sutra), one of the primal scriptures for the Shingon sect.
It is said that it was at the tower in this temple that Kukai discovered "Dainichi-kyo" (Mahavairocana Sutra), one of the primal scriptures for the Shingon sect.
It is said that it was at the tower in this temple that Kukai discovered "Dainichi-kyo" (Mahavairocana Sutra), one of the primal scriptures for the Shingon sect.

sen.j: 空海が撰文した「益田池碑銘并序」（ますだいけひめいならびにじょ）には、「来眼精舎」（くめしょうじゃ）として言及されており、空海とも関係があったと思われる。
sen.e: It is referred to as 'Kume Temple' (in different kanji characters) on the inscription on the monument beside Masuda pond which was written by Kukai, bringing speculation to the relationship with Kukai.

It is referred to as 'Kume Temple' (in different kanji characters) on the inscription on the monument beside Masuda pond which was written by Kukai, bringing speculation to the relationship with Kukai.

It is referred to as 'Kume Temple' (in different kanji characters) on the inscription on the monument beside Masuda pond which was written by Kukai, bringing speculation to the relationship with Kukai.

sen.j: なお、橿原市の隣の明日香村奥山に「奥山久米寺跡」があり、この寺についても来目皇子創建とする伝承がある。
sen.e: The remains of the 'Okuyama Kuma-dera Temple' are found on Mt. Oku-yama in Asuka Village next to Kasahara City, and there is a lore that this temple was also founded by Prince Kume.
The remains of the 'Okuyama Kuma-dera Temple' are found on Mt. Oku-yama in Asuka Village next to Kasahara City, and there is a lore that this temple was also founded by Prince Kume.
The remains of the 'Okuyama Kuma-dera Temple' are found on Mt. Oku-yama in Asuka Village next to Kasahara City, and there is a lore that this temple was also founded by Prince Kume.

sen.j: 久米仙人による開基伝承は『扶桑略記』『七大寺巡礼私記』などのほか、『今昔物語集』巻十二本朝仏法部にも収録され、『徒然草』にも言及されている著名な話である。
sen.e: In addition to "Fuso Ryakki" and "Shichidaiji Junrei Shiki," the tale of the founding by Kume-no-sennin is a famous story that has been recorded in the section regarding Japanese Buddhism in Chapter 12 of "Konjyaku Monogatari-shu" (A Collection of Tales of Times Now Past), and referred to in "Tsuzure-gusa" (Essays in Idleness).

The tale of the founding by Kume-no-sennin is a famous story that has been recorded in the section regarding Japanese Buddhism in Chapter 12 of "Konjyaku Monogatari-shu" (A Collection of Tales of Times Now Past), and referred to in "Tsurezure-gusa" (Essays in Idleness) in addition to "Fuso Ryakki" and "Shichidaiji Junrei Shiki."
sen.cmt: ・「徒然草」のスペルを修正しました。・文頭の句のIn addition toは、このままではthe taleに係るため、「今昔物語集」と「徒然草」に係るよう位置を変えました。
sen.e: The tale of the founding by Kume-no-sennin is a famous story that has been recorded in the section regarding Japanese Buddhism in Chapter 12 of "Konjyaku Monogatari-shu" (A Collection of Tales of Times Now Past), and referred to in "Tsurezure-gusa" (Essays in Idleness) in addition to "Fuso Ryakki" and "Shichidaiji Junrei Shiki."

sen.j: それによると、吉野山龍門寺の久米仙人は仙術で空を飛べるようになったが、ある日空を飛んでいる時、川で洗濯をしている女のふくらはぎに見とれて法力を失い、地上に落ちてしまった。
sen.e: According to the tale, Kume-no-sennin of Ryumon-dera Temple on Mt. Yoshino-yama learned to fly in the air using his supernatural powers; one day while flying, his attention went to the thighs of a woman doing laundry in a river, making him lose his powers and fall to the ground.

According to the tale, Kume-no-sennin of Ryumon-dera Temple on Mt. Yoshino-yama learned to fly in the air using his supernatural powers; one day while flying, his attention went to the calves of a woman doing laundry in a river, making him lose his powers and fall to the ground.
sen.cmt: 「ふくらはぎ」の訳語を修正しました。
sen.e: According to the tale, Kume-no-sennin of Ryumon-dera Temple on Mt. Yoshino-yama learned to fly in the air using his supernatural powers; one day while flying, his attention went to the calves of a woman doing laundry in a river, making him lose his powers and fall to the ground.

sen.j: 久米仙人はその女とめでたく結婚。
sen.e: Kume-no-sennin was able to happily get married to that woman.
Kume-no-sennin was able to happily get married to that woman.
Kume-no-sennin was able to happily get married to that woman.

sen.j: その後は普通の俗人として暮らしていた。
sen.e: Afterwards, he lived as a regular mortal.
Afterwards, he lived as a regular mortal.
Afterwards, he lived as a regular mortal.

sen.j: その後、時の天皇が遷都を行うことになり、俗人に戻った久米仙人は遷都のための工事に携わる労働者として雇われ、材木を運んだりしていた。
sen.e: Later, the emperor of the time decided to move the capital, and Kume-no-sennin was hired as a laborer working on the construction for the move, responsible for transporting lumber and such.
Later, the emperor of the time decided to move the capital, and Kume-no-sennin was hired as a laborer working on the construction for the move, responsible for transporting lumber and such.
Later, the emperor of the time decided to move the capital, and Kume-no-sennin was hired as a laborer working on the construction for the move, responsible for transporting lumber and such.

sen.j: ある日仕事仲間から「お前も仙人なら、仙術を使って材木など一気に運んでしまったらどうだ」とからかわれた。
sen.e: One day one of the other workers teased him, saying "if you're a sennin, why don't you use your powers to transport the lumber in one shot?"
sen.cmt: 仕事仲間が一人か複数人か不明です。
sen.e: One day one of the other workers teased him, saying "if you're a sennin, why don't you use your powers to transport the lumber in one shot?"
One day one of the other workers teased him, saying "if you're a sennin, why don't you use your powers to transport the lumber in one shot?"

sen.j: 一念発起した久米仙人は7日7晩祈り続けた後、仙力を回復。
sen.e: A determined Kume-no-sennin prayed for seven days and seven nights and recovered his powers.
Determined Kume-no-sennin prayed for seven days and seven nights and recovered his powers.
sen.cmt: この場合、人名の不定冠詞は適切でないと思いますので、削除しました。
sen.e: Determined Kume-no-sennin prayed for seven days and seven nights and recovered his powers.

sen.j: 久米仙人の仙術で、山にあった材木が次々と空へ飛び上がり、新都へと飛んで行った。
sen.e: With Kume-no-sennin's powers, all the lumber on the mountain shot into the air one by one and flew to the new capital.
With Kume-no-sennin's powers, all the lumber on the mountain shot into the air one by one and flew to the new capital.
With Kume-no-sennin's powers, all the lumber on the mountain shot into the air one by one and flew to the new capital.

sen.j: これを喜んだ天皇は久米仙人に田30町を与え、これによって建てたのが久米寺である、という話である。
sen.e: The story goes jone to say that pleased with this feat, the emperor gave Kume-no-sennin 12 acres of land, and this is how Kume-dera Temple was built.
The story goes on to say that pleased with this feat, the emperor gave Kume-no-sennin 12 acres of land, and this is how Kume-dera Temple was built.
The story goes on to say that pleased with this feat, the emperor gave Kume-no-sennin 12 acres of land, and this is how Kume-dera Temple was built.

sen.j: 本堂
sen.e: Hondo (Main Building)
Hondo (Main Building)
Hondo (Main Building)

sen.j: 多宝塔（重要文化財）－万治2年（1659年）京都・仁和寺より移築されたもので、桃山様式を残す。
sen.e: Taho-to Pagoda (Multi-treasure Pagoda) (important cultural property) – Momoyama style, relocated from Ninna-ji Temple in Kyoto in 1659.
Taho-to Pagoda (Multi-treasure Pagoda) (important cultural property) – Momoyama style, relocated from Ninna-ji Temple in Kyoto in 1659.
Taho-to Pagoda (Multi-treasure Pagoda) (important cultural property) – Momoyama style, relocated from Ninna-ji Temple in Kyoto in 1659.

sen.j: 隣接する久米御縣神社は、江戸時代までは久米寺の鎮守社となっていた。
sen.e: The adjacent Kumenomiagata-jinja Shrine was Kume-dera Temple's chinju-sha shrine (protectant shrine of a temple) until the Edo period.
The adjacent Kumenomiagata-jinja Shrine was Kume-dera Temple's chinju-sha shrine (protectant shrine of a temple) until the Edo period.
The adjacent Kumenomiagata-jinja Shrine was Kume-dera Temple's chinju-sha shrine (protectant shrine of a temple) until the Edo period.

sen.j: 近鉄南大阪線「橿原神宮前駅」下車、徒歩
sen.e: Walk from Kintetsu Minami-Osaka line Kashiharajingu-mae station.
Walk from Kintetsu Minami-Osaka line Kashiharajingu-mae station.
Walk from Kintetsu Minami-Osaka line Kashiharajingu-mae station.
